title: Anderson Cooper tries a schizophrenia simulator

comments.text:
I have a friend who seemed completely normal, his father passed last summer 
and a few months later he started injecting Meth and possibly Bathsalts. 
 He started saying god is talking to him and he can heal people by touching 
them blah blah. A few weeks later his went to jail, I was hoping he was 
just tripping from meth.  I never messed with it, but read you can go in 
and out of these effects.  Seen him recently and he is still the exact same 
if not worse.  He is saying stuff like his Dad is telling him this and that 
or his dad is in the car waiting on him.  (he`s dead)  Is this 
Schitzophrenia or is it meth or something messing with him?  I have no idea 
if he started back since he got out of jail.﻿
comments.author: Turk420

comments.text:
I have early Schizophrenia and I haven't developed hallucinations or 
delusions yet, so I'm really scared about this.﻿
comments.author: Dead Marco Bott

comments.text:
This is not what the fuck schizophrenia is, please do your research and 
stop telling people lies, it only creates confession. To know what this 
universe or multiverse is capable of or manifesting it is to far from the 
understanding that we have now. Its best to take all possibilities into 
account  before even speaking on such a broad subject. The whole truth is 
out there you just have to search for it (MIND,BODY,SPIRIT). Seek and you 
shell find.....eventually lol. Newton's Flaming Laser Sword.﻿
comments.author: Jerrod Walker

comments.text:
The problem is that you can't accurately simulate schizophrenia. While 
hallucinations can be simulated, you can't possibly simulate the negative 
symptoms which are associated with the drastically poorer quality of life 
and functioning.﻿

comments.text:
My brother lives this way everyday. It's sad. He's gotta be brave and

comments.author: docsbuying

comments.text:
It kinda annoys me when EVERYONE uses this experiment to demonstrate 
psychotic illnesses. Yes, voices suck, but a lot of times you learn to tune 
them out. You might not constantly hear voices, and if you do, they might 
not be saying random things like shown here. My Technicians were there to 
train me, so they were quite focused. You might not hear voices at all, but 
hear other things. And those are just auditory hallucinations. I see things 
out of the corners of my eyes, sometimes forms, usually just movement. I 
feel things touch me. I dissociate. Sometimes my mind is static, or a 
barrage of colors and shapes, that make it impossible to think clearly. 
I'll forget what I was talking about in the middle of a sentence. I'll KNOW 
that I'm in danger in some way, even beyond being monitored. And I also 
know it's very possible reality, as I experience it, doesn't exist.﻿
comments.author: Jace Eksterteran

comments.text:
Could be demonic possession/obsession. All I know is I started developing 
it in 12th grade, 1980, and it went full course in the early 80s. I haven't 
taken psychotropic drugs since the 80s then only for a few months. The 
torture from the medication (Haldol) was markedly worse than the illness 
itself. I was shot up with 2000 mg Thorazine and tied to a bed for a few 
days. The day I was untied a patient, who said he was an angel, asked If I 
wanted to escape. That night he popped some window pane bars out with a 
butter knife and we escaped from a mental health facility. Ever try playing 
volleyball on Thorazine?﻿

comments.author: uhm Laetitia

comments.text:
My husband and I took a Family to Family course through our local NAMI 
chapter, and this test was administered. We all gained a profound insight 
regarding how our loved ones experience their mental illness. It's one 
thing to *think* that you understand someone's pain, quite another to walk 
in their shoes for an hour. Thank you, AC for sharing your experience of 
this test as well as shining a light on a much-maligned and misunderstood 
illness.﻿
comments.author: Pam Hoffmann

comments.text:
My grandmother was schizophrenic and it got to the point of where my mother 
had to pay the bills at 11 years old because her mother, my grandmother, 
couldn't function anymore. I seen the symptoms a couple months before she 
died. She blurted out very derogatory words, such as; bitch, fuck, slut and 
cunt. Words I've never heard her say. I was about 10 years old. She stuck 
her head in our oven twice. It was very strange, and I never knew anything 
was wrong with her until she was dying.

Being schizophrenic must be terrifying. I could never imagine. Although, I 
have manic depression, and during mania and psychosis, I sometimes think I 
am schizophrenic due to my own delusions and paranoias. Mania/psychosis can 
trick the mind into experiencing schizophrenic symptoms which is oddly 
enlightening, but terrifying at the same time.﻿
comments.author: officialbrittanyloveless

comments.text:
+Dark Knight You act as if being Bipolar was some kind of a choice. I was 
born with it genetically, and it took a traumatic event, or events, in my 
life to trigger the disorder to manifest. I'm actually one of the nicest 
people to come by. Yes, I have uncontrollable mood swings that scare 
people, yes I've been manic and didn't know how to come back to reality. 
I've never been a reckless driver. I don't even drive that much because I 
don't want to lose focus and possibly kill someone or myself. I'm well 
aware of what's wrong with me. I'm not insane, because I don't repeat 
mistakes or do I act accordingly to being insane. You'd never know 
something was even wrong with me unless I told you.
comments.author: officialbrittanyloveless

comments.text:
You are the one who is a danger to society, not schziphrenics.  You bipolar 
people who are manic are on a constant rage, I know your type, anger, 
aggression, reckless driving, excessive spending.  Schizophrenics are 
afraid of people unlike bipolar manic people.
comments.author: Dark Knight

comments.text:
+Dark Knight No, I'm not "insane", moron. I have a chemical imbalance which 
is totally treatable. The only time I feel "insane" is when I'm in 
psychosis or extremely manic. But even then, it's not like I'm running 
around hearing voices in my head and screaming at people that they're going 
to burn in hell for wearing the color purple.  Learn more about Bipolar 
before you want to compare it to something like Schizophrenia - who most 
patients are a danger to society being schizophrenic.

comments.text:
okay, so i probably don't have schizophrenia. I think something is wrong

comments.author: John Watson fan

comments.text:
+John Watson fan Sounds like anxiety my friend. That's what that is. You 
just need to figure out your triggers. Keep a close journal and record when 
you feel off and when you feel fine and what you were doing. The distance 
feeling, dissociation, and memory problems can be a symptom of fatigue from 
anxiety. You probably aren't sleeping too well either.
comments.author: daiitokumyouou899

comments.text:
+daiitokumyouou899 I just spend a lot of time worrying about what could 
possibly be wrong with me. I've been like that since a very young age. I 
always thought that I had an illness or disease, and I thought I'd gotten 
over it when I started high school. But now that I'm in college, it's 
started again. My whole life seems off. Like, when you look at an altered 
picture, maybe it's tilted slightly flipped on it's side, and it's really 
hard to tell what is exactly wrong with the picture.. but you just know. 
That's how my whole life feels. And sometimes I honestly feel fine, but 
other times it's so overwhelming. I don't feel depressed, I just feel very 
off. And it's been on and off for months now. I don't know if it has to do 
with stress at college or something else. I'm sorry for rambling to a 
complete stranger on fucking youtube. I just wish I could feel normal 
again. It doesn't help that I'm also having actual dizzy spells lately. 
Feels like I'm trying to walk on a boat in a storm. Nothing feels real. 
When I talk it's like I'm hearing someone else's voice. And other people 
seem so distant. I don't know. I apologize for this tangent.
comments.author: John Watson fan

comments.text:
+John Watson fan A lack of memory is likely due to stress and poor 
sleeping. It is hard to say if you have a physiological problem but 
regardless behavioral changes will have a huge effect. It is the difference 
between being at a 7 or a 10 in terms of anxiety or dissociations. Pay 
attention to what you eat and what you are doing when you feel bad. Routine 
and regular sleep are always important and you may find that on its own 
could significantly improve your quality of living. If you are having 
significant negative symptoms then some kind of drug, something even like 
coffee or cigarettes, might help.

The big problem with negative symptoms though is when trying to treat them 
you might induce mania and you will crash. Balance is key, keep active but 
be chill about it and seek a therapist if at all possible.
comments.author: daiitokumyouou899

comments.author: Kellen vannostrand

comments.author: Petal Foster

comments.text:
I have been living with paranoid schizoaffective disorder for the past 10 
years and to those that think that it's not hard to focus when you have 
different voices talking to you constantly...well I think Mr Cooper just 
proved that it is. Add that to visual hallucinations and tactile ones as 
well - like I experience - and it makes it damn near impossible sometimes. 
I have found (for those out there that are struggling with their symptoms 
right now) that sticking to a routine really helps me. Also helpful for me 
is other auditory stimuli - such as listening to music. It helps to ground 
me in reality and makes it a lot easier for me to focus. 
Living with this illness is in no way easy...and its taken me a long time 
to comes to terms with it and to start living some semblance of a normal 
life. If anyone out there reads this and needs support from someone else 
who has been there please feel free to message me on here. I'll be more 
than happy to talk to you and help you try to come to terms with it. 
But hopefully (like me) it helps to see that you're not alone in this...and 
that there are ways to live some semblance of a normal life﻿

I experienced the schizophrenia simulation earlier on and it is something 
that I never want to have to experience again. After around 10 - 15 minutes 
I felt lost, paranoid, frustrated, scared and upset.

I was listening to music on the computer and when the music was stopped I 
expected the voice to stop with the music...but they didn't. I thought 
there were people looking at me, or they or something was coming to get me.

This has given me both a vivid and emotional insight into those who suffer 
with schizophrenia.﻿

comments.text:
The schizophrenic doesn't hear "voices in his head" the way you mean. 
That's just self-talk and everyone does it to some degree. The 
schizophrenic's auditory hallucinations are things he thinks he's hearing 
outside voices say. That's why we had to hear them to appreciate the 
experiment.

comments.author: urthebest1122

comments.text:
Remember, this is just one symptom.  Add the fleeting images of someone 
dodging out of view, cats walking around the corner or mice running through 
the living room and you began to realize its difficulty...but, there is 
more.  Think that your postal carrier is trying to spy on you, a phone call 
hang up is the gov't tracking you, the pharmaceutical industry poisoning 
your medications, your neighbor is plotting to kill you...

Then you isolate yourself from society because you're afraid.  You have 
trouble thinking clearly, as Cooper illustrated.

It's a debilitating disease.  If someone has brain cancer, you would feel 
sympathetic, but if someone has schizophrenia, then you feel frightened.  

There needs to be more public awareness of this devastating disease.﻿

comments.author: Asociación Tú Decides

comments.text:
Schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorders are very serious and can be 
disabling. Having experienced audio hallucinations due to a medication 
side-effect, I can tell you there's a world of difference between a voice 
inside your head and a voice being piped in.  

Kudos to AC for doing this but IMO it's similar to wearing an empathy belly 
to understand what it's like to be pregnant: it conveys only a small 
portion of the actual experience.  ﻿
comments.author: Carolyn Ross

comments.text:

never hear these voices, because these voices are coming from the devil, 
believe it or not, but it's true. Everyone can try it. Just when you read 
the Quran, you feel so comfortable and you'll be happy. Day by day you will 
never hear these voices again because Allah is behind you and is protecting 
you.﻿

comments.author: Some Thing

comments.text:
If someone deaf had schizophrenia, would they hear voices? I'm not joking, 
i'm dead serious.﻿
comments.author: Sara Gómez (Gakendfay)

comments.text:
+Sara Gómez it depends on why they are deaf. if they became deaf sometime 
during their lifetime and were exposed to sounds and voices, then yes they 
would still hear voices. if they were born deaf, the auditory cortex is not 
active. Therefore, they will not hear voices but they will still suffer the 
other symptoms. Most people born deaf do have an auditory cortex. It just 
isnt working.
comments.author: Athena Zhang

comments.text: +affectivity read my answer :)

Else, even more. But I guess that they would ot fall for it, as they would 
know that they cannot hear real voices.
comments.author: Thing

comments.text: I really appreciate and respect him for doing this﻿
comments.author: Alex Horvath

comments.text:
“Hearing Voices” (actual auditory aberrations) is a reality for many 
Schizophrenics.  However, another shade of gray is that these so called 
“Voices” (as described by the glib) are nothing more than amplified aspects 
of one’s consciousness or thought processes.  Think of the “voice” that 
tells you to look both ways before crossing the road to KFC, but on 
steroids.﻿
comments.author: Joshua Halay

comments.text: Is that really accurate? That simulator? Was that accurate?﻿
comments.author: PatroniMeiSancti

comments.text:
No... it's just all they can do toward an approximation of it.  Like 
someone said, it's kind of like the empathy belly to simulate pregnancy.... 
you get an inkling of what it is, but you know you don't have to wear it 
for 9 months, don't have to go through all the hormonal and physiological 
changes or the worry of the baby you're carrying.  Anderson could have (at 
any time) pulled the headphones off or turned the sound down or off, so he 
knew he didn't have to live with it... a blink of what it's like, but no 
way to simulate the awful reality!

comments.author: Julian Garrett

comments.text:
i'm schizoaffective. i'm happy anderson did this. gets attention to this 
disorder. personally, you get really used to the voices and multitasking 
with them. i'd hear voices 24/7. i'd have conversations with voices and 
people in front of me at the same time. sometimes the conversations would 
get mixed up and i would say the wrong things. sometimes the voices would 
keep me entertained for hours and keeps me up for more than 2 days, 
chainsmoking on the porch. i was a very intellectual person and 
unbelievabley smart. i understand so many things that i have found to be 
true in later times like this year. terms and defintions of things, i heard 
and learned to be real. i found out so much to be true. i understood 
dimensions in a whole nother way, and have read it all to be rather 
descriptively accurate. the disorder is a blessing and a curse. there is an 
alternate reality where we take information from, whether it's a parallel 
universe or just the void, which is what i termed it back in the episodes 
of 2012, the 0th dimension as i knew. which i learned tonight was also 
termed as a void.﻿
comments.author: deeronjepsuhn

comments.text:
yeah i have came up with my own theories. it's crazy seeing the concepts in 
your mind and stuff. being a visual learner, thinking visually is 
interesting.
comments.author: deeronjepsuhn

comments.text:
+deeronjepsuhn At the height of my experience (never got a true diagnosis 
because I don't trust doctors) it was like having fifteen people 
brainstorming at once instead of just one. I came up with a new (at least 
to me) theory on wormholes and how to travel through them. Basically, if 
the universe is a partially filled balloon, and your fingers are gravity, 
you can "push" the sides of the universe together if there is a strong 
gravitational attraction.
But, at around the same time, I was trying t stab my dad with a fork... so, 
I'm just happy it's quieted down now, even if it means I'm a bit "dumber" 
for it...
comments.author: TheArsonator

comments.text: damn man, take care it must be hard to be listening to voices all days
comments.author: cubbex

comments.text:
I hear voices when I am in phycosis but I am having Bipolar 1 and lucky to 
get out of them once and a while. But I am sensitive to people around me 
criticising my behaviour like hallucinating about them not liking me if I 
am behaving strange
comments.author: dog channel

comments.text:
Hi! My friend got same problem and i so happy i found u guys to relate, Is 
it something i can help him with? i really want to help him, he hears 
voices that is good sometimes and evil mostly times, he thinks he know why 
we live in this planet and he can even hear dead celeberties voices, like 
2pac and elvis
comments.author: Marmelo Fernando

comments.text:
It is a double-edged sword, definitely.  I feel that it would be beneficial 
to society as a whole if the positive aspects of the 'disease' were 
cultivated and researched more thoroughly on a cognitive level instead of 
just masked with questionable medications with a sort of send-off attitude 
like "OK take this pill and just go stand off in that corner while we make 
this money."
comments.author: Josh _

comments.text: Shame. Well if it happens again I hope you have a better experience.
comments.author: deeronjepsuhn

comments.text:
That's very neat I've had incounters ware I was able to have an obe since I 
often get sleep paralysis, but i always chicken out and wake my self up 
now. I've had very scary things happen to while in this state so i try and 
snap out of it as soon as possible
comments.author: Randy Butternubs

comments.text:
+Randy Butternubs nice to hear you relate. Yes, I have read articles where 
phycisists describe things I learned in physics. I was obsessed with it the 
year prior to my developing the illness. I love that you commented on this, 
since I have something new I can share. I had a real outer-body experience 
a few days ago and it changed my perspective on what truly this astral 
plane is. There is being lucid in a dream, and there is being awake on the 
astral plane and I realized there is a way bigger different then I 
orignally thought. My OBE was short, but intense and I had way more 
controll than any control I ever demonstrated lucidly in a dream. I look 
forward to my next one, and I will practice OBE technique every day until 
my next venture now. To everyone else, it appears we are not crazy, because 
they believe the same things even if they don't have an illness. You 
probably know what I mean when I say in my endless uncontrollable thoughts 
in my episodes I came up with thousands of possibilities and ideas that 
would PROBABLY translate into abilities in the state of an OBE. I hope to 
take advantage of my spiritual capabilities in my next OBE. I love being an 
agnostic and  having this endearing perspective on this very material world.
comments.author: deeronjepsuhn

comments.text:
Holly fuck Same hear il go nuts and explain how time, light, black holes, 
gravity, dimensions work then later find out some physicist thought of it. 
Some times il go crazy Il start to shake uncontrollably pace back and 
fourth in my room i feel as if I woke up in a lucid dream and relies 
everything around me this is when the craziest theorys come out, I 
generally crash soon after and wake up with a headache and throw our my 
papers because it's would make me look like an idiot crazy person lol
comments.author: Randy Butternubs

comments.text:
Anderson cooper can just take a day off from life and pretend he has
